body: Correct me if I'm wrong, but the entire point of `stickycookies` is that they don't get deleted, right?

Ar far as I interpreted stickycookies, they are persistent for the lifetime of the mitmproxy session, but should still follow cookie semantics. If the server requests that a cookie be removed (for instance if the user logs out explicitely), shouldn't mitmproxy then remove them?

> If the server requests that a cookie be removed (for instance if the user logs out explicitely), shouldn't mitmproxy then remove them?

This is a good question. I think you are right and we should probably delete cookies if the server instructs us to do so.

> A more up-to-date cookie library is probably beneficial here. I'm not sure if there are any
> special reasons for depending on Cookie.py?
> Is it better to attempt to fix cookie.py, or switch mitmproxy to another cookie library?

@cortesi: you have cursed a few times about the cookie stuff IIRC. Can we get your expert opinion here? :smiley:

I agree that the cookies should be deleted when we're instructed to do so by the server. Python's built-in Cookie library is fractally terrible, and fails to parse many common cookies seen in the wild. I'd love to get rid of it entirely (which is why we have our own implementation). I'd be in favor of getting rid of it entirely.

@Kriechi worked on some parts of this during the Honeynet workshop. I think we now only depend on `http_cookiejar.domain_match` from the stdlib? (which I think is fine)

(Does not touch the deletion issue though)

issue.title: Delete stickycookies when told by the server
